Settlers Cottage 1070 Mount Alexander Road Essendon The small four roomed weather-board cottage known as 1070 Mount Alexander Road, North Essendon (and originally known as No 902), was described in Graeme Butler‚Äôs ‚ÄúEssendon Conservation Study‚Äù (January 1985). Whilst, Butler had difficulty in establishing the exact age of the residence, he suggested that it could have been built as early as 1854 by/for Joshua Ewart Cooper, who purchased the part of Arthur Purdon‚Äôs two and three quarter acre Crown Grant (Crown Allotment 36 of the Township of Essendon & Hawstead) on 23rd January 1854. Cooper‚Äôs brother, Thomas Smith Cooper, a coach builder, owned land adjoining his in Marco Polo Street and remained in the area until his death in 1920. The cottage has since been restored This information has been provided by the Essendon Historical Society Est 1970 and relocated to Woodlands Park.

Monday, August 7th, 1905 The T.J. Salts Lumber Company Boiler Explosion A heavy storm came upon the lumber operation and fifteen men gathered for protection under the shed of the boiler building. The boiler ran dry during the storm and the engineer Joe Turner turned on the water supply causing a catastrophic explosion. Men were blown into tree tops and others buried underneath the rubble of the  saw mill. THE DEAD Injured men would also die of their  wounds  some quickly and some years later. phrase: LIVINGSTON DEPOT CENTER & DEPOT ROTARY PARK as the original gateway to Yellowstone National Park. Today, it stands as a restored and community cultural center, preserving the rich railroad heritage of the region. Established in 1902 by the Northern Pacific Railway, the Livingston Depot served maintained by the Livingston Depot Foundation, a non-profit organization We appreciate your cooperation and invite you to enjoy the park respectfully. For more information, please visit www.livingstondepot.org. Depot Rotary Park, adjacent to the historic Depot, is privately owned and dedicated to the preservation and promotion of this landmark. To ensure the park remains a welcoming space for all visitors, prior written from the Livingston Depot Foundation is rquired for all orgainzed events, demonstrations or gatherings held within this park.

phrase: Reincarnation of an Ironstone Wall extensive fundraising, and three years of construction. lesser stature, it held until it could no longer. With the unrelenting A humble ironstone wall had long been vital to this city's function. Tasked with similar demands of the opposing granite wall but of end now rises higher with a back wall of concrete and steel faced Completed in November 2021, these walls now stand as monuments to history, civil pride, and a testiment to the committment of resolute friendship. This plaque, set in August 2025, commemorates this work and the diverse, widespread generousity essential for its completion. spring rains of 2018, the wall's east end collapsed, ultimately leaving its future in the hands of this community. This embankment is again firmly embraced. The original wall's east Community collaboration sparked emergence of a restoration plan, with original stones. Set back overhead are stones gleaned from wall. Custom wire baskets, filled with tons of rock, now support the local sand pits and farms, and individually worked into an additional weakened east wall, threatening the stairway. Behind all this and more lies the steadfast drive and determination of this wall's friends.

"Fuck those fuckin' fans who come out here and say they're Cub fans that are supposed to be behind you rippin' every fuckin' thing you do. I'll tell you one fuckin' thing, I hope we get fuckin' hotter than shit, just to stuff it up them 3,000 fuckin' people that show up every fuckin' day, because if they're the real Chicago fuckin' fans, they can kiss my fuckin' ass right downtown and PRINT IT.  "They're really, really behind you around here... my fuckin' ass. What the fuck am I supposed to do, go out there and let my fuckin' players get destroyed every day and be quiet about it? For the fuckin' nickel-dime people who turn up? The motherfuckers don't even work. That's why they're out at the fuckin' game. They oughta go out and get a fuckin' job and find out what it's like to go out and earn a fuckin' living. Eighty-five percent of the fuckin' world is working. The other fifteen percent come out here. A fuckin' playground for the cocksuckers. Rip them motherfuckers. Rip them fuckin' cocksuckers like the fuckin' players. we got guys bustin' their fuckin' ass, and them fuckin' people boo. And that's the Cubs? My players get around here. I haven't seen it this fuckin' year. Everybody associated with this organization have been winners their whole fuckin' life. Everybody. And the credit is not given in that respect.  "Alright, they don't show because we're 5 and 14... and unfortunately, that's the criteria of them dumb 15 motherfuckin' percent that come out to day baseball. The other 85 percent are earning a living. I tell you, it'll take more than a 5 and 12 or 5 and 14 to destroy the makeup of this club. I guarantee you that. There's some fuckin' pros out there that wanna win. But you're stuck in a fuckin' stigma of the fuckin' Dodgers and the Phillies and the Cardinals and all that cheap shit. It's unbelievable. It really is. It's a disheartening fuckin' situation that we're in right now. Anybody who was associated with the Cub organization four or five years ago that came back and sees the multitude of progress that's been made will understand that if they're baseball people, that 5 and 14 doesn't negate all that work. We got 143 fuckin' games left.  "What I'm tryin' to say is don't rip them fuckin' guys out there. Rip me. If you wanna rip somebody, rip my fuckin' ass. But don't rip them fuckin' guys 'cause they're givin' everything they can give. And right now they're tryin' to do more than God gave 'em, and that's why we make the simple mistakes. That's exactly why." -Lee Elia, April 29, 1983

phrase: Fallen at the ripe old age of 85, Joshua had an eventful life. Born in Brewer Maine, Joshua lived there for most of his life and graduated Bowdoin College to become a language professer in 1852. After educating young minds, Joshua decided to enlist in the army to fight in the civil war. Joshua then participated in the famous battle of Gettysburg, where he was asked to lead the extreme left flank of the Union and led them to the left flank's victory! After his hard 4 years serving the country, Joshua became Governor of Maine and spent the rest of his days ensuring the safety of his home state. This memorial was created to honor the hard work and the accomplishments Joshua fulfilled in his life such as helping people learn, grow, and contributing to the fight against slavery as he was an abolistionist in the war. Having a fountain here at Bowdoin College, Maine, will help people understand what importance he brought to Maine and the country. phrase: I used to live my life in fear Was worried all the time. From waking up to laying down I had no peace of mind. The world became a darkened place a struggle without end and although bitter times those were the days that I began to understand I was only a man I grew up singing songs in church with questions on my mind Then turn my back and ran away from God who gave me life Then one night His presence fell, I wept and shook and knelt I fell down and cried Dear Jesus will you rescue me again? I understand, I'm only a man. And He said,"What will it be now will you choose Me or keep swimming upstream now I've been inside your head hearing you scream out,Well here I am just, take my hand and I'll take out all the things along with all of the fear, all of the fear" I'll give you my burdens Lord "I'll give you peace" All of my desires? "I'll give you what you need" And what about these chains Lord? "I'll set you free" But they're so heavy Lord "Lay them at my feet" I'll lay them at your feet Lord Just promise You won't leave "I'll never leave" So where do I go from here Lord? "Just follow ME, just follow ME" I'll follow you Lord wherever You Lead

phrase: Hampton Villa, c1847 was built by the Hon. Edward Hunt MLC, who was a successful businessman, prominent colonial cabinet maker, councillor on the first Sydney Council and member of the Legislative Assembly.    The design of Hampton Villa is attributed to John Verge, the leading Sydney architect of the period. Hunt hired Verge to build his Jamieson Street showroom and house in 1833, then commissioned the most sought-after architect to build his home.  Typical of Verge, the design includes: sandstone quoining and very fine ashlar construction; deep stone-flagged verandah; hipped roof; generous proportions of rooms; exceptionally high ceilings for the period (14 feet); exceptionally fine cedar joinery that is a dominant feature of the interiors; the use of French doors with slender glazing bars and louvred shutters, including the non-glazed kick-panels in the French doors (a Verge trademark); the elevated situation of building with a commanding hill top view, and the careful situation of the building within a planned and ordered landscape.  Hampton Villa is also associated with a number of prominent colonial personalities, most notably Sir Henry Parkes, who lived at Hampton Villa between 1888 and 1892 during his term as Premier of NSW; and Eliezer Levi Montefiori, businessman, etcher, gallery director and founder of the Art Gallery of NSW in 1880.  Hampton Villa has social significance for its role in the lead up to the Federation of Australia as the home and office of Sir Henry Parkes, as it was the venue for at least one NSW Cabinet meeting and various government business during the 1890 constitutional debates.  The site is also significant for the operation of the Knitting Co, established by the Wilson family, which employed 52 local women in the early years of the twentieth century, making it at the forefront of changing work practices and one of the main employers of women in the Balmain area at this time.  Placed on the State Heritage Register in 2005, Hampton Villa remains as a rare surviving example of an early Victorian marine villa on the Balmain peninsula. Throughout Sydney, villas of this type are becoming increasingly rare. Its prominent position, and maintained views to the water are equally rare as modern harbourside development overshadows earlier surviving colonial structures. Hampton Villa c1847 Built by the Hon. phrase: "Why? Because this wall has long been an enabling part of Bridgeton and Bridgeton has always been an enabling part of me." - Jeff Fogg Reincarnation Of An Ironstone Wall A humble wall of ironstone had here long played a key role in this city's function. At half the height of the opposing wall of granite and holding back the same embankment, it did twice the work, until it could do it no more. In 2018 came unrelenting spring rains, collapse of this wall and then worrying discourse over its viability and future. Enter a local retired engineer and a contractor with a restoration plan that cascaded into months of fundraising, the coming together of two tenacious, aged men, an adventurous search for stones and three years of construction. This embankment is again now soundly retained. This once-failed section of wall is now higher with a 60 foot long cantilevered back wall of steel and concrete faced in salvaged stone. Set back and rising above it is an added wall built from over 80 tons of stone mined from the deposits of sand pits and farmsteads then carted, hammered and chiseled into place. Custom gabion baskets hand filled with 14 tons of rocks now support the failed east wall and previously endangered Completed in November 2021, these walls now stand testament to a resolute friendship and as monuments to history, civic pride and enablement. integral to its fulfillment, this plaque is set - March 2023. __________ JEFF BROOKS, RANDY DICKINSON, KENNETH MAYHEW R W HARVEY, CLIFF MECOUCH FOR DONATIONS OF SCARCE IRONSTONES WITHOUT WHICH THE SUCCESS OF THIS PROJECT WOULD NOT HAVE BEEN POSSIBLE. SPECIAL THANKS TO JEFF AND SANDY AS TWO TENACIOUS AGED MEN 33 YEAR-OLD HALF-TON PICKUP TRUCK NELLIE JUAN PEREZ CONTRACTOR/ TEOCOS CONCRETE JEFFREY R 'JEFF' FOGG PROJECT ENGINEER & MANAGER EDWARD 'SANDY' FEDDEMA & FLAVIA ALAYA PROPERTY OWNERS KEY PARTICIPANTS To remember this work, this commitment and community generosity so stairway. Behind all this and more is the unwavering resolution of the two men.

phrase: San Manuel Band of Mission Indians his people into the San Bernardino Valley. Long before we would be Before the arrival of European settlers. Before Santos Manuel led called the San Manuel Band of Mission Indians, our Tribe had a name. It echoed across the highlands, passes, valleys and mountains. It was not the name we adopted to survive a hostile world. It was not attached to any foreign concept, like ‚ÄúMission Indians.‚Äù It was not given to us by others, so it could never be taken away. This name was our own, spoken in our language and rooted in our traditions. Today, its spirit lives on in all of us. It is forever part of our history. It is the heart and soul of our sovereignty. It is why we must reclaim our namesake for our ancestors and the generations to come. This is who we are. This is who we have always been. We are the People of the Pines. We are Yuhaaviatam. It was known among our Maara‚Äôyam people and to other tribes.

phrase: Ko te Mauri K≈çwhatu - ko Te Manga The Binding Energy of the Sacred Rock - Te Manga The tohu k≈çwhatu or sacred stone known as Te Manga has it's origin in the upper reaches of the Mangatutu stream. Te Manga was found and specially prepared by a small group of tangata whenua for the karakia whakarite - the blessing ceremony signifying and enabling the commencement of the building project. Te Manga was buried on 26th October 2018 beneath the paved space that is now the area directly in front of the entrance to this building. The K≈çwhatu Tira or steel rock sculpture, is a visual depiction of Te Manga, a representation of it's origins from Ranginui and PapatuƒÅnuku. Pupuritia ngƒÅ tohu whenua o ngƒÅ t≈´puna, he taonga m≈ç nga whakatupuranga e haere ake nei Hold on to the special places of our ancestors for they are treasure for the generations to come _________ Te Whakatere o Te Maumahara The Navigator of Memories This sculpture holds two time capsules containing memorial content from Maniapoto ki te Raki and Raukawa, and the Department of Corrections.  The centre shape is a Hoe Whakatere - the steering paddle, and symbolizes the journey and navigation through life.  The names of our t≈´puna are reflected in the shapes and etchings on the sides. E t≈´ ki te kei o te waka, kia pakia koe e ngƒÅ ngaru o te wƒÅ. Stand at the stern of the canoe and feel the spray of the future biting at your face. Commissioned by Harold Te Piki K≈çtuku, Chairperson,- Maniapoto ki te Raki Crafted by Greg Te Kanawa & Dylan Te Kanawa _________

Reincarnation of an Ironstone Wall  A humble ironstone wall had long been crucial to this city's function. Serving the same retention purpose as the opposing granite wall, but at half its height, it effectively performed twice the work until it could no longer. In 2018, unrelenting spring rains caused the wall's east end to collapse, leading to discord in the city about who was responsible for restoring it.  A retired local engineer devised a restoration plan that resulted in collaboration with a generous contractor, extended fundraising, the partnership of two unrelenting men in their seventies, and three years of construction.    Once again, this embankment is securely in place. A taller wall now stands behind this plaque, featuring a 60-foot-long back wall made of concrete and steel, faced with salvaged stone. Set back and rising above it is an additional wall constructed from over 80 tons of raw stone mined from local sand pits and farmsteads, which were transported, hand-shaped, and meticulously positioned. Custom wire baskets, filled by hand with 14 tons of rock, now support the deteriorating east wall and the previously threatened stairway. Behind all this and more stands the unwavering determination of the two men.  Completed in November 2021, these walls now stand as a testament to resolute friendship and as monuments to history, civic pride, and commitment.   This plaque is dedicated in June 2025 to commemorate this work and the community's generosity, which was integral to its fulfillment. ____________________________________________  KEY PARTICIPANTS EDWARD ‚ÄòSANDY‚Äô FEDDEMA & FLAVIA ALAYA   PROPERTY OWNERS JEFFREY R. FOGG   PROJECT ENGINEER & MANAGER JUAN PEREZ   CONTRACTOR / TEOCOS CONCRETE  NELLIE   A 33-YEAR-OLD HALF-TON PICKUP TRUCK  SPECIAL THANKS TO  R W HARVEY, CLIFF MECOUCH,   JEFF BROOKS, RANDY DICKINSON & KENNETH MAYHEW  FOR THEIR DONATIONS OF SCARCE IRONSTONE, WITHOUT WHICH THE SUCCESS OF THIS PROJECT WOULD NOT HAVE BEEN POSSIBLE. ____________________________________________ R W HARVEY, CLIFF MECOUCH, JEFF BROOKS, RANDY DICKINSON & KENNETH MAYHEW community's generosity, which was essential to its completion. phrase: Reincarnation of an Ironstone Wall  A humble ironstone wall had long been crucial to this city's function. Serving the same retention purpose as the opposing granite wall, but at half its height, it effectively performed twice the work until it could no longer. In 2018, unrelenting spring rains caused the wall's east end to collapse, leading to discord in the city about who was responsible for restoring it.  A retired local engineer devised a restoration plan that resulted in collaboration with a generous contractor, extended fundraising, the partnership of two unrelenting men in their seventies, and three years of construction.    Once again, this embankment is securely in place. A taller wall now stands behind this plaque, featuring a 60-foot-long back wall made of concrete and steel, faced with salvaged stone. Set back and rising above it is an additional wall constructed from over 80 tons of raw stone mined from local sand pits and farmsteads, which were transported, hand-shaped, and meticulously positioned. Custom wire baskets, filled by hand with 14 tons of rock, now support the deteriorating east wall and the previously threatened stairway. Behind all this and more stands the unwavering determination of the two men.  Completed in November 2021, these walls now stand as a testament to resolute friendship and as monuments to history, civic pride, and commitment.   This plaque is dedicated in June 2025 to commemorate this work and the community's generosity, which was integral to its fulfillment. ____________________________________________  KEY PARTICIPANTS EDWARD ‚ÄòSANDY‚Äô FEDDEMA & FLAVIA ALAYA   PROPERTY OWNERS JEFFREY R. phrase: The Lauderdale Lakes Country Club golf course owes it's existance to the tenacity of numerous area residents who stepped in to save it from development during its 100-plus year history. The course was created in 1921 to use by guests of the nearby Sterlingworth Hotel. In 1936, Lakes resident Edwin Hawks Ravenscroft bought and redesigned the course, which he had to shutter during World War II. At the end of the war, another resident, Waldemar Petersen, formed a group to buy the course from Ravenscroft and manage it. The group included: Chuck Morton, as secretary; Harold Leasley, as president; Petersen, as treasurer; and Phil May, Harold  Mattes, Harold schmid, Harold Pittman, Kirk shareholders. The group bought the course in December 1945, with Morton acting as volunteer manager. In 1973, after expanding the clubhouse, the group sold the course back to the Steringworth. Between 1973 and 1983, the course's zoning requirements were changed to allow multi-family condominium development, placing its continued existence in jeopardy. At this time a second group of concerned residents, led by Dennis Petersen (no relation). stepped in to save the property as a golf course. They kept i it off the development market until 1996. Waldemar Petersen's son, Jerry Petersen(as chairman of the newly formed Lauderdale Lakes Lake Management District), led the effort to buy the course and make it into a municipal course. The District acquired wetlands bordering the course along the shore of Mill Lake and placed the property in a conservation easement to ensure that it continues as open space. Thanks to all these far-sighted Lakes residents, the Lauderdale Lakes Country Club remains an enjoyable open space and Betty Avery, and Kenneth Holsman and Emily Morrison, as benefiting the whole community.
